text: Augustus III, Frederick Augustus II (17 October 1696 — 5 October 1763) was the King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania from 1 October 1733 until his death in 1763. He was the only legitimate son of Augustus II the Strong of Poland. He was adapted to Catholicism in 1712 to secure his position for the Polish throne. In 1719 he married Maria Josepha of Austria, a daughter of Joseph I, Holy Roman Emperor and sister of the Holy Roman Empress Maria Amalia, and became the Elector of Saxony in 1733 following his father's death. He gained support of Joseph's brother Charles VI by agreeing the Pragmatic Sanction of 1713 and also gained recognition from Russian Empress Anna by supporting Russia's claim to the region of Courland. He was elected king of Poland by a small minority on 5 October 1733 and afterwards banished the former Polish king Stanisław I. He was crowned in Kraków on 17 January 1734. ==Royal titles== Royal titles in Latin: Augustus tertius, Dei gratia rex Poloniae, magnus dux Lithuaniæ, Russiæ, Prussiæ, Masoviæ, Samogitiæ, Kijoviæ, Volhiniæ, Podoliæ, Podlachiæ, Livoniæ, Smolensciæ, Severiæ, Czerniechoviæque, nec non- hæreditarius dux Saxoniæ et princeps elector etc. English translation: August III, by the grace of God, King of Poland, Grand Duke of Lithuania, Ruthenia, Prussia, Masovia, Samogitia, Kiev, Volhynia, Podolia, Podlachia, Livonia, Smolensk, Severia, Chernihiv, and also hereditary Duke of Saxony and Prince- Elector, etc. ==Notes== ==References== ==Other websites== Category:1696 births Category:1763 deaths Category:Kings of Poland Category:People from Dresden Category:Grand Dukes of Lithuania Category:Electors and Electresses
title: Augustus III of Poland
